Events, Requests, Responses and Exception Handling

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AsyncResponseProcessor<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    A AsyncResponseProcessor is an application callback to handle the response from a request.
    Message
    Message wraps the user/application AsyncRequest/Event which are queued in the Blade's targetReactor's inbox.
    MessageSource
    A source of messages, and which must be able to handle a response.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AsyncRequest<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    AsyncRequest instances are used for passing both 1-way and 2-way buffered messages between blades.
    BoundResponseProcessor<RESPONSE_TYPE>
    A thread-safe wrapper for a AsyncResponseProcessor.
    Event<TARGET_BLADE_TYPE extends Blade>
    An Event instance is used to pass one-way unbuffered messages to any number of Blade objects.
    EventBus<TARGET_BLADE_TYPE extends Blade>
    Publishes events to subscribers.
    RequestBase<RESPONSE_TYPE>  
    SignalResponseProcessor
    Used to flag a message as a 1-way message.

Package org.agilewiki.jactor2.core.messages Description

Events, Requests, Responses and Exception Handling

There are two types of messaging, 1-way (events) and 2-way (request/response).

Event Messages

Event messages are created and passed using subclasses of the Event class. An event is not bound to an blade instance, so the same event can be used to doSend messages to any number of blades. And when passing an event message to an blade, the message is given to the target blade's processing immediately, without buffering.

AsyncRequest/Response Messages

In contrast, request messages are created and passed using anonymous subclasses of the AsyncRequest class, with these anonymous classes present within the blade where the request message is evaluated. Response messages are simply request messages to which a response has been assigned. AsyncRequest and response messages are aggregated and sent in blocks to reduce the overhead of having to pass individual messages.

No messages are being processed when a message block is sent. So when the last message block is sent, the thread migrates to the destination targetReactor along with that block. More often than not, only a single block of messages is sent, so thread migration significantly reduces the overhead of message passing.

Exception Handling

Exception handlers are used to process otherwise uncaught exceptions. But if there is no exception handler, or if an exception is thrown by an exception handler, then the exception is returned as a response, though if the current message being processed is an event then the exception is simply logged. When a response message that holds an exception is processed by the source targetReactor, the exception is rethrown within the source blade rather than being pass back to the blade as a valid response.

Before an event or a request is processed, the current exception handler is set to null. The application logic specific to that event or request then has the option of assigning an exception handler via the Reactor.setExceptionHandler method. When a request message is sent, the current exception handler is saved in the request message and subsequently restored when a response is received.
